text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with potato leek soup that's right
we're doing the only soup that
successfully leads a double life
although there could be others we
haven't found out about but as far as we
know this is the only one since if you
serve it hot it's potato leek soup but
if you serve it chilled it also goes by
the name of vichyssoise which is quite
delicious it would probably be easier to
rhyme with but since it's kind of chilly
and damp out we're gonna be going with
the hot version and to get started with
this delicious soup the first thing
we're gonna have to do is take a leak
actually like for leaks and we're gonna
need to trim them up and while most
recipes say to just use the white and
very light green parts I do like to
include about an inch or two of that
dark green so I'm gonna cut mine right
there and then we can go ahead and cut
off that root end and split it
lengthwise and usually we wash our
veggies before we cut them but because
leeks are famous for having dirts and
hiding between all those layers what we
need to do is cut this first and then
wash it so we'll simply split that
lengthwise and cut it across as shown oh
and I should mention when you buy the
leeks we're gonna need a pound and a
half after trimming okay which is
probably gonna be like four or five
weeks to paint on the size so I just
wanted to mention in case you bought a
pound and a half leeks after trimming
that wouldn't be enough and then once
all our leeks are sliced we'll transfer
that into a large bowl and fill that up
with nice cold fresh water and then
we'll get in there with our hand and
swish it around and swish it around good
and what's happening as you do this any
silt or sand or dirt is falling to the
bottom of the bowl and if we lift those
leeks out of the water
post agitation they should be pretty
clean and by the way depending on how
dirty they are to start with we could do
that three or four times if necessary so
I did that twice but that's gonna be up
to you I mean you are the boss to making
sure your leek is on fleek but anyway
once our leeks are trimmed washed and
drained we are ready to move to the
stove where we're gonna begin this
recipe using the classic French soup
method which is exactly like all the
other soup methods except we use twice
as much butter so we'll go ahead and
melt a dangerously large amount of
butter in our soup pot set over
medium-high heat and once that melts or
at least partially melts we can go ahead
and transfer in our leeks and then we'll
also want to toss in a spoon of salt and
what we're going to do is cook these
leeks stir
on medium high until they just sort of
start to break down and soften up all
right which is going to take I don't
know three or four minutes and then what
we'll do when they start to slump and
sort of kind of look like this is we'll
reduce our heat down to medium and cook
these for at least thirty minutes or
until very very very soft and please do
not rush this step it is the key to the
entire recipe okay so we're gonna let
those cook in that butter on medium heat
stir it occasionally for like I said at
least thirty minutes although it could
take more no guarantees and one thing we
can do to keep ourselves entertained
while we're waiting is to go ahead and
prep our potatoes and my favorite
variety of potato for soup would be the
Yukon Gold I like the taste and texture
but I also think they give this soup an
even more beautiful color and all we
need to do to prep these would be to
peel them and cut them in smaller pieces
so I cut mine into ADEs and then we'll
just keep those in some water so they
don't turn brown while we're waiting for
our leeks to finish speaking of which
let's go take a look and you're probably
thinking those look nice and soft I
would stop right here well they were
close but not quite as soft as I wanted
so I gave those about another 10 minutes
until they look like this so you really
do want to go this far it is critical to
the recipe they should be very very soft
and almost paste like and at this point
we go ahead and drain our potatoes and
add those to the pots along with some
more salt as well as our cooking liquid
which in my case is gonna be chicken
broth although a lot of recipes call for
vegetable stock which I've never made
since I've never been able to find
vegetable bones so I'm gonna go with the
chicken broth and then what we need to
do at this point is adjust our heat to
maintain a gentle but steady simmer and
we'll simply cook these potatoes until
they're very very soft and exactly how
long that's gonna take I'm not even
gonna guess that because I'm assuming we
didn't cut our potatoes exactly the same
size so we're just gonna let those
simmer until they're perfectly tender
and this is me about a half hour later
checking mine except I'm using a wooden
spoon which is definitely not the right
tool for this job
so I grabbed a fork to verify what I
suspected and I confirmed that they were
very soft which means we can move on to
the blending step and I'm gonna do mine
right in the pot with a submersion
blender but if you don't have one you
can just do this in batches with a
regular blender but be careful don't
burn yourself now that is some quality
advice
anyway I'm gonna use my stick blender
and even though we're gonna add some
more liquid to this I always think it's
easier to blend something like this
smooth if we leave it thick so it might
take a minute or two but once those
larger chunks break down you should only
be a minute or two away from a very very
smooth puree so that is looking just
about perfect right there and then what
we'll do once that's been accomplished
is go ahead and finish this off with
some heavy cream whoo check it out
heart-shaped drips anyway we're gonna
add some heavy cream as well as a nice
big spoon of creme fraiche oh and by the
way don't worry if you can't find creme
fraiche I'll provide a link on the blog
post to a video that we showed you how
to make your own but anyway we're gonna
stir that in and our soup is pretty much
done except for two very important
things we of course need to make sure
this heats back up since we just added
some cold cream and creme fraiche plus
of course we're gonna have to taste for
seasoning and I determined mine needed
as it so often does a little more salt
and then I just couldn't help myself I
also added a little bit of cayenne
although I will admit white pepper would
be more traditional so I'm gonna go
ahead and stir that in and like I said
wait for this to come back up to serving
temp we don't really need it to come
back to a rolling boil but we do want to
serve this soup piping hot and once we
are happy with the temperature and the
taste we'll go ahead and ladle that up
into some nice preheated bowls only
crazy people serve soup and cold bowls
and then I finished up with a little
extra swirl of creme fraiche which was
exactly one drip away from perfection
and then we'll finish up with a few
chives and that's it our potato leek
soup is done and not only is it gorgeous
and warm and comforting it is also one
of the most delicious soups of all time
and we have those slow-cooked leeks to
thank for that
and I forget what it is that makes them
so delicious and savory actually might
be the glutamates
is it the glutamates it could be the
glutamates but anyway just an
extraordinarily satisfying and savory
soup which would be very easy to screw
up by trying to add a lot of extra stuff
in here so while I usually encourage you
to add whatever you like maybe this one
time just follow the recipe as is
although have you said that
I doubt a handful of crispy bacon would
ruin this but anyway the point is this
is fantastic as is and sure it does take
a little bit of time but you know what
they say there are great soups and there
are fast soups but there are no great
fast soups
and this my friends is truly a great
suit so I really do hope you give this a
try soon head over to food wishes calm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
[Music]
